title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Ray Bradbury
quote_last: The soul’s midnight. The tide goes out, the soul ebbs. And a train arrives at an hour of despair. Why?

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Douglas Adams
quote_first: According to her watch it was shortly after
quote_last: , and according to everything else it was night-time.
quoteSourceTitle: The Long Dark Tea-time of the Soul

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Raymond Chandler
quote_last: I was walking the floor and listening to Katchaturian working in a tractor factory. He called it a violin concerto. I called it a loose fan belt and the hell with it.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Russell Hoban
quote_time_case: three o' clock in the morning
quote_last: Eurydice is bound to come into it. After all, why did I sit here like a telegrapher at a lost outpost if not to receive messages from everywhere about the lost Eurydice who was never mine to begin with but whom I lamented and sought continually both professionally and amateurishly. This is not a digression. Where I am at three o' clock in the morning - and by now every hour is three o' clock in the morning - there are no digressions, it’s all one thing.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-F. Scott Fitzgerald
quote_time_case: at three o’clock in the morning
quote_last: , a forgotten package has the same tragic importance as a death sentence, and the cure doesn’t work – and in a real dark night of the soul it is always three o’clock in the morning, day after day.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Amit Chaudhuri
quote_first: Early mornings, my mother is about, drifting in her pale nightie, making herself a cup of tea in the kitchen. Water begins to boil in the kettle; it starts as a private, secluded sound, pure as rain, and grows to a steady, solipsistic bubbling. Not till she has had one cup of tea, so weak that it has a colour accidentally golden, can she begin her day. She is an insomniac. Her nights are wide-eyed and excited with worry. Even at
quote_last: in the morning one might hear her eating a Bain Marie biscuit in the kitchen.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Philip Roth

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Max Frisch
quote_first: Once I saw a figure I shall never forget. It was
quote_last: , as I was going home from Blacky as usual; it was a short-cut for me, and there would be nobody in the street at this time of night, I thought, especially not in this frightful cold.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Philip K Dick
quote_first: Roused from her sleep, Freya Gaines groped for the switch of the vidphone; groggily she found it and snapped it on. ‘Lo,’ she mumbled, wondering what time it was. She made out the luminous dial of the clock beside the bed.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-David Foster Wallace

quote_last: milk-switches? It doesn’t ring true, Jim.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Ray Bradbury
quote_last: , thought Charles Halloway, seated on the edge of his bed. Why did the train come at that hour? For, he thought, it’s a special hour. Women never wake then, do they? They sleep the sleep of babes and children. But men in middle age? They know that hour well.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-Jerome K Jerome
quote_first: What’s the time?“ said the man, eyeing George up and down with evident suspicion; "why, if you listen you will hear it strike.” George listened, and a neighbouring clock immediately obliged. “But it’s only gone
quote_last: !” said George in an injured tone, when it had finished.

title: $:/litClock/times/-03:00-George Eliot
quote_last: in the morning and I’ve got all my faculties as well as ever I had in my life. I know all my property and where the money’s put out. And I’ve made everything ready to change my mind, and do as I like at the last. Do you hear, Missy? I’ve got my faculties.”
